title: Termux doesn't terminate ssh connection on exit
body:
If I ssh to a machine, and then press Exit in the notification, the ssh process on the server keeps running. This is especially visible when exiting an attached tmux session, since that session will stay attached which causes the viewport of other sessions to be reduced to the size of the phone.

Note that this happens on my new Pixel 3, but did not happen on my previous Nexus 4. They both have version 0.65, so I'm not sure what's the difference.

title: xargs seems to be consuming stdin
body:
While trying to read some filenames from a file and removing them interactively, `xargs` seem to be consuming stdin. So the interactive mode doesn't work:

```
u0_a117@localhost ~/G/nnn> xargs -0 -a ~/.nnncp rm -ir
rm: remove '/data/data/com.termux/files/home/GitHub/nnn/nnn'? ⏎                                            u0_a117@localhost ~/G/nnn>

u0_a117@localhost ~/G/nnn> xargs -0 -a ~/.nnncp rm -ir
rm: remove '/data/data/com.termux/files/home/GitHub/nnn/CHANGELOG'? rm: remove '/data/data/com.termux/files/home/GitHub/nnn/LICENSE'? rm: remove '/data/data/com.termux/files/home/GitHub/nnn/Makefile'? ⏎
u0_a117@localhost ~/G/nnn>
```

However, as the input is from a file (using option `-a`) this should work as it does on all Linux (Tested on Ubuntu and the Linux subsystem for Windows).

title: Add support of <ESC>[3J to clear scrollback
body:
In macOS terminal / KDE Console / xterm, the `printf '\e[3J'` is used to clear the scrollback.  Could you also support it for compatibility?

Reference:
1. https://askubuntu.com/questions/25077/how-to-really-clear-the-terminal
2. https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/31872/how-do-i-reset-the-scrollback-in-the-terminal-via-a-shell-command

title: With no menu button, I can't find a way to close a session
body:
Without having a menu button, I can't find a way to close a session in termux. There's "Exit" in the notification which terminates all sessions, and of course I can type "exit" but that only works if there's nothing blocking running in the terminal - but I can't find any way to close a *single* session while keeping the others open.

The most obvious way would be to add a close button to each entry of the sessions sidebar, but there doesn't appear to be any.

title: Please install file by default
body:
Hi,

This is more of a request than an issue. It seems like `file` is not installed by default in the Termux environment.

My utility `nnn` requires `file` to detect the file type. So far I haven't come across any environment where it's not available by default.

Would it be possible to install `file` by default (during installation) on Termux?

```
mux!

Wiki:            https://wiki.termux.com
Community forum: https://termux.com/community
IRC channel:     #termux on freenode
Gitter chat:     https://gitter.im/termux/termux
Mailing list:    termux+subscribe@groups.io

Search packages:   pkg search <query>
Install a package: pkg install <package>
Upgrade packages:  pkg upgrade
Learn more:        pkg help
=========
 IPython
=========

Tools for Interactive Computing in Python
=========================================

    A Python shell with automatic history (input and output), dynamic object
    introspection, easier configuration, command completion, access to the
    system shell and more.  IPython can also be embedded in running programs.

Usage

    ipython [subcommand] [options] [-c cmd | -m mod | file] [--] [arg] ...

    If invoked with no options, it executes the file and exits, passing the
    remaining arguments to the script, just as if you had specified the same
    command with python. You may need to specify `--` before args to be passed
    to the script, to prevent IPython from attempting to parse them. If you
    specify the option `-i` before the filename, it will enter an interactive
    IPython session after running the script, rather than exiting. Files ending
    in .py will be treated as normal Python, but files ending in .ipy can
    contain special IPython syntax (magic commands, shell expansions, etc.).

    Almost all configuration in IPython is available via the command-line. Do
    `ipython --help-all` to see all available options.  For persistent
    configuration, look into your `ipython_config.py` configuration file for
    details.

    This file is typically installed in the `IPYTHONDIR` directory, and there
    is a separate configuration directory for each profile. The default profile
    directory will be located in $IPYTHONDIR/profile_default. IPYTHONDIR
    defaults to to `$HOME/.ipython`.  For Windows users, $HOME resolves to
    C:\Users\YourUserName in most instances.

    To initialize a profile with the default configuration file, do::

      $> ipython profile create

    and start editing `IPYTHONDIR/profile_default/ipython_config.py`

    In IPython's documentation, we will refer to this directory as
    `IPYTHONDIR`, you can change its default location by creating an
    environment variable with this name and setting it to the desired path.

    For more information, see the manual available in HTML and PDF in your
    installation, or online at https://ipython.org/documentation.html.

Subcommands
-----------

Subcommands are launched as `ipython cmd [args]`. For information on using
subcommand 'cmd', do: `ipython cmd -h`.

profile
    Create and manage IPython profiles.
kernel
    Start a kernel without an attached frontend.
locate
    print the path to the IPython dir
history
    Manage the IPython history database.
qtconsole
    DEPRECATED, Will be removed in IPython 6.0 : Launch the Jupyter Qt Console.
notebook
    DEPRECATED, Will be removed in IPython 6.0 : Launch the Jupyter HTML Notebook Server.
console
    DEPRECATED, Will be removed in IPython 6.0 : Launch the Jupyter terminal-based Console.
nbconvert

    DEPRECATED, Will be removed in IPython 6.0 : Sign notebooks to trust their potentially unsafe contents at load.

    DEPRECATED, Will be removed in IPython 6.0 : Manage Jupyter kernel specifications.
install-nbextension

Options
-------

Arguments that take values are actually convenience aliases to full
Configurables, whose aliases are listed on the help line. For more information
on full configurables, see '--help-all'.

--debug
    set log level to logging.DEBUG (maximize logging output)
--quiet
    set log level to logging.CRITICAL (minimize logging output)
--init
    Initialize profile with default config files.  This is equivalent
    to running `ipython profile create <profile>` prior to startup.
--autoindent
    Turn on autoindenting.
--no-autoindent
    Turn off autoindenting.

    Turn on the auto calling of magic commands. Type %%magic at the

--no-automagic
    Turn off the auto calling of magic commands.

    Enable auto calling the pdb debugger after every exception.

    Disable auto calling the pdb debugger after every exception.

    Enable auto pretty printing of results.
--no-pprint
    Disable auto pretty printing of results.

    Disable using colors for info related things.

--autoedit-syntax
    Turn on auto editing of files with syntax errors.
--no-autoedit-syntax
    Turn off auto editing of files with syntax errors.
--simple-prompt

--no-simple-prompt
    Use a rich interactive prompt with prompt_toolkit
--banner

--no-banner
    Don't display a banner upon starting IPython.
--confirm-exit
    Set to confirm when you try to exit IPython with an EOF (Control-D

--no-confirm-exit
    Don't prompt the user when exiting.

--no-term-title
    Disable auto setting the terminal title.

    Gives IPython a similar feel to the classic Python prompt.
--quick
    Enable quick startup with no config files.
-i
    If running code from the command line, become interactive afterwards.
    It is often useful to follow this with `--` to treat remaining flags as
    script arguments.

    Default: 0
    Choices: (0, 1, 2)
    Make IPython automatically call any callable object even if you didn't type
    explicit parentheses. For example, 'str 43' becomes 'str(43)' automatically.
    The value can be '0' to disable the feature, '1' for 'smart' autocall, where

--colors=<CaselessStrEnum> (InteractiveShell.colors)

    Choices: ['Neutral', 'NoColor', 'LightBG', 'Linux']
    Set the color scheme (NoColor, Neutral, Linux, or LightBG).
--logfile=<Unicode> (InteractiveShell.logfile)

-c <Unicode> (InteractiveShellApp.code_to_run)
    Default: ''
    Execute the given command string.
-m <Unicode> (InteractiveShellApp.module_to_run)
    Default: ''
    Run the module as a script.
--ext=<Unicode> (InteractiveShellApp.extra_extension)
    Default: ''
    dotted module name of an IPython extension to load.
--gui=<CaselessStrEnum> (InteractiveShellApp.gui)
    Default: None
    Choices: ['glut', 'gtk', 'gtk2', 'gtk3', 'osx', 'pyglet', 'qt', 'qt4', 'qt5', 'tk', 'wx', 'gtk2', 'qt4']
``` 

title: Feature Request: Add the ability to run Termux commands via. ADB without root.
body:
Currently, in order to run a command, you have to do something like this:
```cmd
adb shell am start -n com.termux/.app.TermuxActivity
adb shell input text "[command here]"
adb shell input keyevent 113 && adb shell input keyevent 66
```
which, in my opinion, is a little hackey... There are a lot of things that could stop this script, like the screen being locked or a Termux session already being open with text typed in.

I propose that a new Activity/Service is added (or an extension of `com.termux/.app.TermuxService` to allow use by ADB). You could possibly even allow another app (with user granted permission) to run a command!

This would be BEYOND useful (and a little cool, too), like being able to start up `sshd` and setup port forwarding completely from the computer! You wouldn't even have to unlock the screen, assuming that you have already accepted the computer's RSA Fingerprint on your phone.

<hr>

If something to allow this already exists, just let me know and I can change the title and close the "*Issue*".

title: Feature request: auto default session name
body:
I thought instead of sessions being numbered, they could have a default name that either matches the current working directory, or if a command is running and has focus, such as vim, show the command's name and arguments. Like, if you run `vim myfile.txt`, it'll change the title to that, and if you close or suspend vim, the title returns to the CWD. Then when you name a session, you'd also have the option to clear the name and restore defaults.

I think this would help keep track of what's being done with each session without having to name them. What do you guys think?

title: Prevent accidental key press when swiping the extra keys view to the left to access the text input view
body:
The title says it all.

User needs to be careful what key to lay his finger on when swiping the extra keys view, because when the swipe begins it registers as key press. One example for all: the "ARROW_UP" button will fill in previous command, this obstructs the new command you are about to type in the text input view.

title: termux-clipboard is not so easy to install (in order to support copy paste via pbcopy, pbpaste commands)
body:
On macOS X, the `pbcopy` and `pbpaste` command can be used to manipulate the clipboard.

On Desktop linux that's the `xclip -selection` command, so I made `alias pbcopy='xclip -selection clipboard'` and `alias pbpaste='xclip -selection clipboard -o'` for the command to be portable with macOS X.

That's very useful for a lot of text replacement applications :

```bash
pbpaste > file.txt     # into a file
pbcopy file.txt        # from a file
cat file.txt | pbcopy  # from a file, using a pipe
pbpaste | sed 's/ /-/g' | pbcopy  # direct replacement of clipboard
pbpaste | python 'import sys
sys.stdout.write(sys.stdin.read().replace(" ", "-"))
' | pbcopy  # use python for more complicated Operations !
pbpaste | python replace_stuff.py | pbcopy  # why not from a python file ?
```

I have no clue how clipboard work in android but I think that's manageable !

title: Fix Termux crash on malformed config file
body:
When having an malformed json input in the extra-keys property, the termux-app crashes later with an NullpointerException due to an uninitialized mExtraKeys variable.

This fix improves the parsing of the properties file. In case of an invalid "extra-keys" property, the variable will be initialized with length 0.

title: Support setting Termux as home launcher
body:
## Overview

This addresses #206 (along with #482 and #880), but in a more canonical way than I suggested in the comments there.

As for launching applications, we can use `am`

```
am start --user 0 <intent>
```

Personally, I wrap these in aliases in my bashrc and it works quite well:

```
app_launch() {
        am start --user 0 "${1}"  >/dev/null
}

alias settings='app_launch "comm.android.settings/.Settings"'
```

## Thoughts

Obviously, my method above requires manual curation. The most annying part is getting the intent uri for newly installed apps, but in #206 @thewisenerd demonstrates one method of easing that hurdle.

title: Please add READ_LOGS to list of requested permissions
body:
Please add android.permission.READ_LOGS to app's list of requested permissions.

That way (non-root) users could do (just once after getting their phone)
$ adb shell pm grant com.turmux android.permission.READ_LOGS

Enabling then in the app doing e.g.,
$ logcat -d -b radio | grep OPERATOR
etc. things that were formerly impossible.

One could now run shell scripts that could precisely pluck data from
logcat and post-process it, much more pinpoint than any bulky logcat
app... Or GPS app... or cell tower id app... !

title: Support styled underlines
body:
It would be great if support could be added for styled underlines.

Here's a brief overview:
- `\e[4:1m` straight underline
- `\e[4:2m` double underline
- `\e[4:3m` curly underline

**Note**: the colon is strictly required, as something like `\e[4;1mHello\e[0m` would print a bold, underlined "Hello" to the console. This is discussed in the [neovim issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7479#issuecomment-348783792).

Support for this was added to neovim in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7479, and in tmux (so far without color support) in https://github.com/tmux/tmux/issues/1492. There's an idea floating around that the underline can be given a color using `58:2:<r>:<g>:<b>` or `58:5:<x11 color>`, similar to how it's done for true colors. From what I've read, `CSI 59` resets the underline color. (I'm not a terminal developer, so please forgive me if I'm butchering these terms).

Here's an example:
```bash
echo -e '\e[4:3;58:2:255:100:0mHello\e[0m'
```
![undercurl](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3069239/46876270-836d4400-ce03-11e8-9a12-1ad5bb9a7f9b.PNG)
This produces "Hello", with an orange wavy underline. I've tested it and it works on both [mintty](https://github.com/mintty/mintty/wiki/Tips#text-attributes-and-rendering) and [kitty](https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/protocol-extensions.html#colored-and-styled-underlines).

title: DNS issues with terraform
body:
I am trying to use terraform within termux to provision AWS infrastructure.  I have a basic tf file that just tries to use the aws provisioner.  When I run `terraform init` on my mac or ubuntu hosts, it downloads the plugin without issue.  When I try on termux, I get the following error:

`Error installing provider "aws": Get https://releases.hashicorp.com/terraform-provider-aws/: dial tcp: lookup releases.hashicorp.com on [::1]:53: read udp [::1]:37606->[::1]:53: read: connection refused`

I have read that there are possible issues with the go dns resolver that may cause this, but I'm unsure of how to correct it.  I am able to perform a nslookup on the domain above and get the proper DNS entries returned.

#210 looks to be a similar issue, but they were running go code and terraform is a precompiled binary for linux 64bit.  I am running this on a chromebook with an intel processor.  `dpkg --print-architecture` shows i686.  I was able to install golang and run the sample code from #210 and that worked fine.

title: Can it be used in 4.4.2 devices?
dpkg for Termux doesn't correctly supports x86-64 Android devices - x86_64 vs x86-64 vs amd64 name of architecture for packages and repo paths dispute
body:
I usually install Termux on my `x86_64` devices (more often on Asus Zenfone 2 ZE551ML Z00A/Z00AD) from Google Play or F-Droid and by default repos in `APT` (`/etc/apt/sources.list`) and architectures in `dpkg` (`/var/lib/dpkg/arch`) configured to support packages only of i686 architecture, but Intel Atom Z3580 CPU in my device supports `x86_64`, `i686` and `arm (ARMv7)` archs well.
And I can not change this behaviour of Termux - `dpkg` doesn't allow to add architecture through `dpkg --add-architecture x86_64`, 'cause character `'_'` in `x86_64` not allowed by `dpkg`, but packages repo (http://termux.net/dists/stable/main/binary-x86_64, http://termux.net/dists/stable/InRelease, http://termux.net/dists/stable/Release) configured exactly with underscore (`'_'`) characters everywhere.
Certainly, I manually install `http://termux.net/dists/stable/main/binary-x86_64/dpkg_1.19.0.5_x86_64.deb` and `http://termux.net/dists/stable/main/binary-x86_64/liblzma_5.2.4_x86_64.deb` with `dpkg -i --force-all *.deb`, change repos in `APT` and archs in `dpkg` configurations, but whatever I do - this doesn't helps and correct this situation.
So, unfortunately, I cannot install `x86_64` packages, but this relates not only me and has more wide impact, 'cause app doesn't support `x86_64` devices well enough.

![screenshot_2018-09-30-15-32-30](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7407420/46257071-94e65000-c4d5-11e8-8696-85be43d1a8ab.png)

![screenshot_2018-09-30-15-32-19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7407420/46257070-944db980-c4d5-11e8-8d0b-2521e65175d5.png)

![screenshot_2018-09-30-17-20-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7407420/46257072-94e65000-c4d5-11e8-986a-e5b191f5f279.png)

title: No completion or cursor movement when in `su`
body:
For some reason, when I'm root (i.e. after running `su`), all the control chars are taken literally (as if the shell was not interactive) rather than as commands to manipulate the input.
More specifically, TAB just inserts a TAB character rather than displaying completions, `C-a` inserts a character of ASCII code 1 (displayed as `^A`), ...

Along the same lines, after hitting RET to send the command, the command is echoed back before the actual command's output.  I tried `tsu`, but it suffers from the same problem.

One odd detail I noticed along the way is that while `tty` responds `/dev/pts/0` when I'm not within `su`, it switches to `/dev/pts/1` when I'm in `su`.

These problems do not affect `su` in `adb shell`, so apparently there's some way to "make it work right".

This is under LineageOS-15.1, using LineageOS's standard "su addon" and running the latest Termux package from F-Droid.

title: Cron repeats tasks unnecessarily
body:
Hello,

Every time I make a cron script it gets repeated like four or five times at execution. So if I make a test script like * * * * * date > date.txt then it will say 19:09 19:09 19:09 19:09 19:09 in the output file. Anyone knows how to fix this?

title: Lost write access on sdcard after Android 7->8 upgrade
body:
When I updated my phone (Moto Z) from Android 7 to Android 8 termux lost write-access to the sdcard. I do still have read+write access to the internal storage at /storage/emulated/0 and I still have read access on the sdcard. But writing/deleting files is met with a permission-denied error. 

I don't have root (and never has had on this phone). 

Snippets of ls reveals that _everybody_ lacks the write permission for the sdcard.
```
$ ls -l /storage/emulated/0
drwxrwx---    6 root     everybod      4096 Sep  2  2017 DCIM
[...]

$ ls -l /storage/30303030-2d30-3030-3000-020000000000/
drwxr-x---    5 root     everybod    131072 Jan  5  2017 Android
drwxr-xr-x    3 root     everybod    131072 Dec 28  2016 DCIM
[...]
```

I do have write access to the termux-directory on the sdcard (/storage/30303030-2d30-3030-3000-020000000000/Android/data/com.termux/files), where the user-owner is set to u0_a94.

Not sure if it matters but I the sdcard was previously (in android 7) mounted at
/storage/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000 (which I thought was weird)
whereas in Android 8 it is
/storage/30303030-2d30-3030-3000-020000000000

All other applications that I use can still access and create files on the sdcard as ususal (and not just their own _Android/data_ directory). I've ran termux-setup-storage again and although it fixed the symlinks to the new sdcard mount it didn't do anything for the permissions. Also tried to reinstall termux but the behavior is the same. 

```
$ termux-info
Updatable packages:
All packages up to date
System information:
Linux localhost 3.18.71-perf-g259b8d6 #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Jun 29 08:01:20 CDT 2018 aarch64 Android
Termux-packages arch:
aarch64
Android version:
8.0.0
Device manufacturer:
motorola
Device model:
XT1650
```

title: Copying text mishandles newlines
body:
When I highlight and copy multiple lines from Termux and paste somwhere else like a web browser, it appears that Termux incorrectly copies the empty space between the last character of a line and right edge of the window as many spaces.

In addition to all the extra spaces, the newline character is aften missing (~ 70% of lines), so multiple lines are merged into one.

title: gdb fails to attach to non-termux processes with assertion error
body:
gdb fails to attach to non-termux processes with assertion error. This happens right after typing `attach <pid>`:

```linux-nat.c:1093: internal error: int linux_nat_post_attach_wait(ptid_t, *int *): Assertion `pid == new pid' failed.```

This is of a normal `org.example.myapp` test app, it's not a system app or anything and runs a single process. (I ran gdb inside `tsu -e` because otherwise, I don't appear to have the permissions to attach to a non-termux process at all)

title: make TermuxService (com.termux.service_execute) available to other apps
body:
So, any app can use the TermuxService execute.

Only minor changes in AndroidManifest.xml are needed:
      ```
      < permission android:name="com.termux.app.TermuxService">
      < /permission>

      <service android:name="com.termux.app.TermuxService" android:permission="com.termux.app.TermuxService">
          <intent-filter>
            <action android:name="com.termux.service_execute" />
          </intent-filter>
        </service>
```

title: Alternative patch to fix fn-up fn-down pgup/pgdown
body:
- in onKeyDown() ignore keys when the Fn key is pressed
- in onKeyDown() return false when the key is not handled.

The above two changes fix the handling of Fn-key combo's on devices with
a physical keyboard, allowing the android system defined fallbacks from
`/system/usr/keychars/Generic.kcm` to be properly handled.

Fixes #731.

Original diagnosis and fix by Konehaltia.

title: close sessions without waiting for user input except the last one
body:
An attempt to deal with these issues:

 * https://github.com/termux/termux-app/issues/627
 * https://github.com/termux/termux-app/issues/56

This PR makes sessions be closed automatically without pressing enter. However to close last session user will have to press enter - this allows to start a 'fallback' session so user can fix things if normal session can't be started.

title: Updated configurable keys
body:
Here's an rebased and updated version of @neverwin's configurable keys (https://github.com/termux/termux-app/pull/650). Ping @robertvandeneynde since you had good input in previous PR.

<s>Some stuff remains: I haven't managed to get the property parser to accept arrow keys in termux.properties, if I for example try `extra-keys = [['ESC','/','―','HOME','↑','DEL','-'],['TAB','CTRL','ALT','←','↓','→','PGDN']]` I get:

![ss_2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18900601/43368524-aa77aa2a-935e-11e8-93ab-7a58e5712558.jpg)
</s>


Which I suppose is a UTF-8/UTF-16 error, and should be fixable.. 
Writing `extra-keys = [['ESC','/','\u2015','HOME','\u2191','DEL','-'],['TAB','CTRL','ALT','\u2190','\u2193','\u2192','PGDN']]` instead works: 

![ss_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18900601/43368522-a438efa2-935e-11e8-9c53-e919710bd29e.jpg)

I also think that the keys take up too much vertical space, making the rows smaller would be nice. @xqdoo00o I suppose that this is what you are doing in https://github.com/termux/termux-app/pull/759? But that works only for android 5? I didn't notice any big difference when I merged it (https://github.com/Grimler91/termux-app/tree/configurable_keys_smaller)

Also, more importantly, **we/I need to add more validation of the `extrakeys` field!** If, for example, two rows of different lengths are given the app crashes on start-up (with no change of fail-safe session).

--------------------

I've also set the default extra keys to default to the single row we had before, and made the extra keys visible per default. Users who want several rows can configure it.

We should definitely ship a default termux.properties file with all the different options as comments, they are a bit secret as mentioned in the previous PR.

I've also kept the "swipe up from - for |" and "swipe up from / for \" features, though they are less needed with configurable keys.

title: Window size issue
body:
After using Termux for a few hours on my tablet (LineageOS 15.1 / Oreo 8.1), the window size will get stuck, such that when I rotate it to portrait mode, only 2/3 of the terminal will be used, the bottom 1/3 will remain empty.  If I rotate it back to landscape, the entire screen is used.  It will remain like this, even after force closing Termux, until I reboot.  It will then be fine for a few hours.  I haven't figured out what trigers it yet -- it seems to be random.

Any idea what could be wrong or how I can debug it?

title: mv doesn't work outside of /home inside proot
body:
If I am inside a proot chroot, I get the following
```
bash-4.4$ pwd
/home
bash-4.4$ touch a
bash-4.4$ mv a b
#If CWD is /home it works, however anywhere else:
bash-4.4$ mkdir test
bash-4.4$ cd test
bash-4.4$ touch a
bash-4.4$ mv a b
mv: cannot move 'a' to 'b': No such file or directory
```

If I am not using proot if works fine.

Running proot as below:
```
exec /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/proot -b /system:/system -b /vendor:/vendor -b /data:/data -b /property_contexts:/property_contexts -b /storage:/storage -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr:/usr -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin:/bin -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/etc:/etc -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/lib:/lib -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/share:/share -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/tmp:/tmp -b /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/var:/var -b /dev:/dev -b /proc:/proc --cwd=/home -r /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/.. /bin/bash -l
```

EDIT:  A couple more things I noticed.

1. If b exists, it works
```
bash-4.4$ mkdir test
bash-4.4$ cd test
bash-4.4$ touch a
bash-4.4$ mv a b
mv: cannot move 'a' to 'b': No such file or directory
bash-4.4$ touch b
bash-4.4$ mv a b
bash-4.4$ ls
b
```

2. The location of the file does not matter, only CWD.
```
bash-4.4$ mkdir test
bash-4.4$ cd test
bash-4.4$ touch ../a
bash-4.4$ mv ../a ../b
mv: cannot move '../a' to '../b': No such file or directory
bash-4.4$ cd ..
bash-4.4$ touch test/a
bash-4.4$ mv test/a test/b
bash-4.4$ ls test
b

```

title: Persistent Home Directory
body:
What I'm looking for is a nice, convenient way to store configuration settings for externally running applications in Termux. For example, when I install Midnight Commander (mc) or `pip install youtube-dl` or edit my `~/.vimrc` or `~/.bashrc`, etc... I would like my settings to still exist even when I remove Termux, even by accident (somehow).

Let's say, I give Termux storage permissions (now possible starting with Nougat). So then, somewhere in `/sdcard/` directory, I should then be able to make a directory where I can store dotfiles and settings for applications, like a "second home folder" if you will.

Is it as simple as using a home directory symlink, or appending something to $PATH, or is this more complex?

Something more of a streamlined solution would be great to add to Termux!

title: Wrong timezone in Go
body: I'm running [Hugo](https://gohugo.io) on my Nexus 5 via Termux (thank you, by the way, for this amazing contribution to humanity) and when I changed the datestamp on a post manually to the current time, I noticed that Hugo did not build my post because it thought the time was in the future. That's when I realised that it had written the date stamp with a timezone of Z while creating the post instead of +01:00 (I'm on Irish Standard Time at the moment). ## Context * Time and timezone on the phone is set and displayed correctly * In a Termux session, `date` produces the right time and date and timezone (IST) * getprop persist.sys.timezone produces the correct timezone (Europe/Dublin) ## To replicate The following basic Go app produces the wrong timezone consistently for me both under plain Termux and under termux-chroot: ```go package main import "time" import "fmt" func main() { p := fmt.Println t := time.Now() p(t.Format(time.RFC3339)) } ``` ## Sample output ```bash date Wed Jul 4 16:48:28 IST 2018 getprop persist.sys.timezone Europe/Dublin go run time.go 2018-07-04T15:48:37Z ``` So Go thinks its on UTC even though we're on IST. ## Update I’ve just verified on my Mac that this is erroneous behaviour in Termux and not an anomaly specific to Go. The output of the same script and the corresponding `date` results are in the screenshot below: ## Update 2 As a further check, the issue does not exist in Node.js under a Termux session. The following code: ```javascript let t = new Date().toTimeString() console.log(t) ``` Produces: ```bash 17:38:36 GMT +0100 (IST) ```

title: Add permission WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE
body:
`WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` provides write access to emulated SD card ("internal storage"). However for some reason it provides only read access to real SD card. This is what happen before and after `WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` is granted respectively on my phone:

```
$ id
uid=10312(u0_a312) gid=10312(u0_a312) groups=10312(u0_a312),3003(inet),9997(everybody),20312(u0_a312_cache),50312(all_a312)
$ ls -ld /storage/emulated/0
drwxrwx--x 87 root sdcard_rw 4096 Jul  2 15:17 /storage/emulated/0
$ ls -ld /storage/3436-3531
drwxrwx--x 5 root sdcard_rw 32768 Jan  1  1970 /storage/3436-3531
```

```
$ id
uid=10312(u0_a312) gid=10312(u0_a312) groups=10312(u0_a312),3003(inet),9997(everybody),20312(u0_a312_cache),50312(all_a312)
$ ls -ld /storage/emulated/0
drwxrwx--- 87 root everybody 4096 Jul  2 15:17 /storage/emulated/0
$ ls -ld /storage/3436-3531
drwxr-xr-x 5 root everybody 32768 Jan  1  1970 /storage/3436-3531
```

As you can see, although both storage paths' owner group changes from `sdcard_rw` to `everybody` after the permission is granted, the group permission of that of the real SD card changes from `rwx` to `r-x`.

From the data/etc/platform.xml in current platform/frameworks/base master, I can see that the group `sdcard_rw` (along side with `media_rw`) is provided by an undocumented permission named `WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE`. Therefore, proposing to add the permission to the manifest.

P.S. Not tested so I have no idea if it actually works as expected. Would be great if someone at liberty to build the app can help test this.

title: Request: multi-display xterm
body:
To have a single `termux` window extend over two android devices.

One logical window, but the top half displayed on one physical display, and the bottom half displayed on a second display, on another android device. "Casting" the bottom half of the display.

With `tmux`, it's possible to duplicate a display on another device, by connecting to the same session, but it doesn't seem possible to display different parts on different devices.

Would it make sense for `termux` to have this halfscreen-casting functionality?

title: Request: horizontal mouse wheel (from left/right touch swipes)
body:
This is really useful in `vim`, when you turn off line wrapping (`:set nowrap`) to get more lines per screen (or, use a larger font), and you can easily scroll to see the few lines that extend off the right of the screen.

termux already converts up/down swipes into mouse wheel events, so you can scroll. In `vim`, these can be mapped like:

```
  map <ScrollWheelUp> <C-Y>
  map <ScrollWheelDown> <C-E>
```

But `vim` can also accept horizontal mouse wheel events:

```
  map <ScrollWheelLeft> z<Left>
  map <ScrollWheelRight> z<Right>
```

But termux doesn't seem to be generating them.

This seems like it would be simple to add, and it wouldn't interfere with the swipe from the left to bring up the window list and keyboard/new session, because that starts from the edge of the display.

title: Sends broadcast on app open to notify addon termux receivers
body:
This is needed to allow https://github.com/termux/termux-api/pull/185 to work

* Sends a one time broadcast upon app launch to allow the optional TermuxAPI to perform the new checks in the mentioned PR. It has no coupling to the TermuxAPI, other than checking to see if there are any receivers that can listen to the broadcast action, which was needed to support Android Oreo.

title: chromeos: better support for using terminal mouse events AND selection/copy?
body:
I use Termux (latest available in Play Store) on ChromeOS (66.0.3359.203 on an Asus C301S) and run a number of console programs that can accept terminal mouse input (emacs, weechat, tmux). When a console program accepts mouse input, Termux passes the mouse events through and it works nicely, but at the same time, it disables the long-press to open the selection menu. Thus, my choice is to use terminal mouse events XOR to be able to copy text from Termux to ChromeOS. (Note: paste from ChromeOS to Termux is unaffected, b/c the hardware keyboard Ctrl+Alt+V allows it to work.)

I have currently handled this by explicitly disabling terminal mouse events in my Termux dotfiles. However, this is suboptimal because it represents a (currently the only) difference between my regular Linux dotfiles and Termux dotfiles, and using the mouse in console programs is occasionally useful. If I can get a way of using terminal mouse events AND copying text from Termux to ChromeOS, then I can use a single set of dotfiles for both environments.

I'm thinking of two alternative ways to solve this:

1. A new hardware keyboard shortcut to activate the selection menu. This would probably be the easiest, but I'd rather avoid making more Termux shortcuts that might conflict with peoples' existing keybindings.

2. Provide a way to switch from the regular popup menu (activated by keyboard shortcut Ctrl+Alt+M) to the selection menu. You can currently switch from the selection menu to the regular popup menu by clicking the "More..." button; perhaps there could be a "Selection..." button to switch from the regular popup menu to the selection menu?

Another alternative that I'm guessing would be more complex to implement:

3. Gnome Terminal has a similar issue that terminal apps accepting mouse events disables its built-in mouse actions. With Gnome Terminal, when you hold the Shift key, mouse events are handled directly by Gnome Terminal and not passed through to the app running in the terminal.

Any thoughts or ideas?

title: Alt-V volume keybinding interferes with readline

Firstly, thanks for this amazing project.  I use it all the time.

title: documents provider: mime type map fails with .JPG
body:
The mime type for .JPG files exported to the Storage Access Framework via the documents provider is the fallback application/octet-stream; thus, image viewers won't open it.

Given that file extensions are usually case insensitive and the library appears to only recognize lower-case variants (tried .html, .doc and .txt), and that digital cameras often store uppercase letters, I suggest that lowercasing the extension before [here](https://github.com/termux/termux-app/blob/master/app/src/main/java/com/termux/filepicker/TermuxDocumentsProvider.java#L199) as a mitigation.

(I can't tell whether there might be better ways than using webkit's mimetypemap (maybe libmagic?) -- but lowercasing would mitigate the immediate issue).

Thank you for maintaining termux and the documents provider; it makes [dealing with the android file system limitations](http://git-annex.branchable.com/forum/Dealing_with_crippled_Android_file_system/) much better!

Ideally, these should be customizable so that the user can choose the most appropriate action.

title: google-Repository required for compilation because some dependencies were removed from jcenter()
Replace \n with \r when pasting (Fixes #678)
body:
Termux will now properly send `\r` to the terminal instead of `\n` when pasting multiline strings.

This fixes `cat` not repeating back lines and `nano` accidentally justifying text (because `\n` maps to `^J`), as well as other potential issues.

This matches the behavior of other terminals, such as iTerm2 which explicitly does it here:
https://github.com/gnachman/iTerm2/blob/f8a5930/sources/iTermPasteHelper.m#L113

title: True italic font support
body:
Currently, italic fonts are achieved by making the current font oblique. It would be great if it would use the italic font instead.

Here's how I envision it could work: Similar to using a custom font with `~/.termux/font.ttf`, put an italic font in a file called `~/.termux/font-italic.ttf`. Then run this:
```bash console
$ termux-reload-settings
$ echo -e '\e[3m light fixture \e[0m' # characters that look different in italics
```
and it would print this:
_` light fixture `_

---

I tried running `file usr/lib/libmp3lame.so`, and output is

title: Add hundreds of downloadable fonts to termux (discussion)
body:
So I modded the [Termux-Styling](https://github.com/termux/termux-styling) app to support android's new [downloadable font](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/look-and-feel/downloadable-fonts) feature, but I ran into two issues that need resolving:

*  Downloadable fonts requires a valid font provider.  The most popular one is Google Play, but that means that Google Play is required to be installed to get access to them.  No big deal, can fallback to the current bundled fonts if it's not installed.

*  The thing is though, when you request one of the downloadable fonts, you're handed a [TypeFace](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/Typeface) object, NOT a .ttf file, which is what the Styling app currently needs to save for the Termux app to use.   You can easily [go from a font file to a TypeFace object](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/Typeface.html#createFromFile(java.io.File)), but not vice versa.  So while I can currently get the Typeface in the styling app, there's not much I can do with it.

There is another option, which is to use Google's font API to get the actual URI to the .ttf file for the font, and then use the Termux Styling app to download that file and copy it into the right place.  This wouldn't require modifying anything in Termux app, but it would require entering a ([freely available](https://developers.google.com/fonts/docs/developer_api#APIKey)) API key to be able to access that and that might be too annoying to add this.  Might also as a FOURTH option make a list of all the .ttf paths but that may change in the future.

The question-- would it make more sense to just add the downloadable font support to the termux app itself?  It would barely add any size to the app footprint (in fact could make it smaller if you're not loading all those unused fonts in Styling) and fonts are cached by Google Play and reused between apps.  Downside would be that (1) this doesn't affect color stuff, (2) it does have the Google Play dependency and so wouldn't add much for FDroid users, and (3) I am unclear as to whether then you move the color support into termux app or keep the styling or what.

Just throwing it out there if anyone wants to offer any thoughts or opinions.

title: Console renders standard variants as emoji's
body:
Greetings,

it seems according to
http://www.unicode.org/Public/6.1.0/ucd/StandardizedVariants.html
that a number of unicode characters have 2 variations (text style and emoji style).

And Termux renders (at least for the suit characters ♠ ♥ ♦ ♣) in emoji style which is wrong for a terminal, especially when those characters appears in a curses app. The emoji style will actually override the color assigned by the curses app.

To reproduce, just copy paste the following into the terminal: ♠ ♥ ♦ ♣
This does not happen in the Cygwin Shell or the Tera Terminal.

title: Pasting via long press causes issues in some programs
body:
Newlines when pasting have strange effects.

This is most noticeable and reproducable in nano.

Steps to reproduce with nano:
Put this into a file:
```
This
Is
A
Test
```
Copy the file contents to the clipboard:
```
cat file | termux-clipboard-set
```
Open that same file in `nano -w`, put the cursor to the beginning, long press, paste.
```
ThisThis Is A Test Is A
Test
```
Should be:
```
This
Is
A
Test
This
Is
A
Test
```
or similar. The same version of `nano` on iTerm2 has no issue, so it is likely a Termux issue.

`cat` also has this issue:
Manually:
```
$ cat
This
This
Is
Is
A
A
Test
Test^D
$
```
With clipboard:
```
$ cat
This
Is
A
TestThis
Is
A^D
Test^D$
```
Upon the first `^D`, Test is shown, and then the second finishes the `cat` without an ending newline.

title: Request: Option to open Help Pages in Browser
body: Any chance you could add a link to the Touch Keyboard commands page from the popup menu that's displayed onLongClick in the main terminal? The multi-key commands are difficult to reference from inside the app, and it would be really helpful if they opened in the browser in their own activity that was accessible in the Recents/Overview screen. This way users could quickly switch between the terminal and the browser app, or put their device in split-screen mode and look at the commands while entering them in the terminal.

title: logcat hangs on API 24
body:
[Using SSH](https://termux.com/ssh.html) suggests to use ``logcat`` to view the log output from ``sshd`` but on API 24 ``logcat`` hangs. ``adb logcat`` works just fine though.

Running [termux-setup-storage](https://wiki.termux.com/wiki/Termux-setup-storage) has the nice side-effect of making ``logcat`` work again. I do not know if this is expected. Maybe the [Using SSH](https://termux.com/ssh.html) wiki could be updated to suggest to also run ``termux-setup-storage``. I may be missing something though.

title: TIOCGWINSZ reports zero window rows/cols until screen is rotated
body:
Ok finally figured out why mosh was sometimes having issues from within my chroot in termux: when termux is first opened, it will report the window size as 0 rows and 0 columns, but if the screen is rotated while termux is open, it will then report the correct rows and columns from that point forward.

This python script can be used to test this:
```
import sys, struct, fcntl, termios
s = struct.pack('HHHH', 0, 0, 0, 0)
t = fcntl.ioctl(sys.stdout.fileno(), termios.TIOCGWINSZ, s)
print(struct.unpack('HHHH', t))
```

Before the screen is rotated, it will output `(0,0,0,0)`, but after it's rotated, it will output something like `(26,96,0,0)`.

title: Kindle Fire HD8 uses 32 bit binaries
body:
The system binaries on the Kindle Fire HD 8 are 64-bit, but Termux installs the 32-bit binaries.

System binary
```
$ file /system/bin/sh
  /system/bin/sh: ELF 64-bit LSB shared object, ARM aarch64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /system/bin/linker64, stripped
```

Termux binary
```
$ file $PREFIX/bin/bash
 /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/bash: ELF 32-bit LSB shared object, ARM, EABI5 version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /system/bin/linker, stripped
```

CPU info
```
$ lscpu
Architecture:        armv8l
Byte Order:          Little Endian
CPU(s):              4
On-line CPU(s) list: 0-3
Thread(s) per core:  1
Core(s) per socket:  4
Socket(s):           1
Model:               3
Model name:          AArch64 Processor rev 3 (aarch64)
CPU max MHz:         1300.0000
CPU min MHz:         600.0000
Flags:               half thumb fastmult vfp edsp neon vfpv3 tls vfpv4 idiva idivt lpae evtstrm aes pmull sha1 sha2 crc32
```

title: Incorrect terminal window size in pixels reported by TIOCGWINSZ
body:
I'm trying to use a command line application from within termux that queries TIOCGWINSZ to get the terminal window size in pixels, but when run from within termux, it always returns zero.  Example with python:

```
$ python
Python 3.6.4 (default, Jan 24 2018, 23:01:57)
[GCC 7.2.1 20180116] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import sys, struct, fcntl, termios
>>> s = struct.pack('HHHH', 0, 0, 0, 0)
>>> t = fcntl.ioctl(sys.stdout.fileno(), termios.TIOCGWINSZ, s)
>>> print(struct.unpack('HHHH', t))
(24, 87, 0, 0)
```

If I ssh into termux from my laptop (using xterm), the same command returns the correct window size in pixels.

title: Play Store now forbids downloading executable code
body:
https://play.google.com/about/privacy-security-deception/malicious-behavior/

> Apps or SDKs that download executable code, such as dex files or native code, from a source other than Google Play.

To remain in compliance with the guidelines, Termux would need to put each package into an apk installed from the Play Store instead of doing package management internally.

I thought you might appreciate a heads up about this.

title: "Storage" permission not available in app settings
body:
Hi. I am trying to have write access to an external USB drive from Termux with no success.
From what I have learned, the process should be: run termux-setup-storage, and allow the permission when the pop-up shows up. I have done that multiple times, and the "storage" directory is created, but it doesn't contain the symlink to "external". If I run "df", I can see how the USB disk is already mounted in /storage (read only), but, as I say, the symlink is not created.

After checking, I noticed that, in the Termux settings page, under "Permissions", there is no Storage permission available for enabling or disabling, only a "Memory" permission, which is already enabled. Could this be the reason of "$HOME/storage/external" not being created?. If so, is there any way to make the Storage permission appear?, or is this a bug?

Thanks and keep up the good work.

```
extrakeys = [["ESC","CTRL","ALT","TAB","―","/","|"]]
```
That's the default one of Termux.

title: Temp never gets cleaned
body:
/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/tmp should probably get cleaned whenever Termux does a cold start, or after a reboot.

For example, the sorin-async prompt creates a unique temp file each time you open a shell. Granted, it is zero bytes, but the point is that nothing ever gets deleted.

title: Illegible background using "Black on white" or "White on black" themes
body:
I use the "Black on white" color scheme, which displays text without colors.

When programs attempt to change the background color, the text should still be legible when using the "Black on white" or "White on black" scheme, but in fact both the foreground and the background are often black.

This script illustrates the problem:

```
#!/bin/bash

echo $'Black   \e[40mbackground\e[m'
echo $'Red     \e[41mbackground\e[m'
echo $'Green   \e[42mbackground\e[m'
echo $'Yellow  \e[43mbackground\e[m'
echo $'Blue    \e[44mbackground\e[m'
echo $'Magenta \e[45mbackground\e[m'
echo $'Cyan    \e[46mbackground\e[m'
echo $'White   \e[47mbackground\e[m'
```
Screenshots of the resulting output (on my Moto G5+ running Android 7.0) are here:
https://imgur.com/gallery/1DlEb, showing the output with the "Solarized Dark", "Black on white", "White on black", and "Solarized Light" color themes.

I first noticed this problem running `tmux` under Termux. The status line at the bottom of the screen is just a black bar with the "Black on white" theme. (There should be a way to work around this in `tmux`. I'm still trying to find it, but that's not the subject of this bug report.)

title: Random system freezes when starting new session via sidebar
body:
## Description

Sometimes, when starting a new session through the apposite button in the left sidebar, the whole system freezes after the session has started, in the midst of the bar hiding animation, prompting the need for a reboot by means of holding the `Power` button.

-----

## System info

OS: LineageOS 14.1
Android version: 7.1.2

Device: Samsung S4 Mini
Variant: I9195

Kernel: custom
Xposed installed: yes
Root: yes

`uname -a`: `Linux localhost 3.4.113-Remix-CM14-v.19-g63edfc9 #1 SMP PREEMPT Thu Oct 26 10:57:57 EDT 2017 armv7l Android`

-----

## Footnotes

It doesn't seem possible to trigger this apparent bug at will. Sometimes, it happens right after starting Termux; other times, it manifests when doing other work in the background. I was not able to capture it in a logcat yet.

As of now, it happened both with and without Xposed installed, and both on Marshmallow and Nougat.

If in need of more info, ask away.

title: Termux:Sudo Addon proposal
body:
Hi,

I recently started to use Termux. And I find it very interesting. For years I have used other Linux-on-Android systems; but I think this project is superior: simple and effective.

After this short intro I propose a new idea around the “su” and “sudo” commands. Please, note that this isn’t a request of “how to use root in Termux” or “scripts for sudo”. I know about such tools, and this is a _different_ proposal:

- The problem: If you grant the root permission to Termux, then _any_ script running inside it can obtain root privileges (very bad!).

- The solution: Create a new Termux Add-on, called Termux:Sudo. This addon will be another _different_ Android App. This new application will have an structure similar to Termux:API, so it can communicate with the Termux shell environment. But this new app focuses on running processes with elevated privileges. In consequence, this Termux:Sudo is the _only_ app that needs to receive the root privileges.

- The implementation: The new Termux:Sudo will maintain an internal password for root (obfuscated) and a list of grant commands (or ‘*’ for all). So the function is very similar to the “sudo” command, and configured in the same way. Note that the data of Termux:Sudo App is _inaccessible_ from the Termux environment, so the password and configuration is even secure.

- The use: When you call for example “sudo nano /system/build.prop” a password command is presented prior to execute the binary.

What you think about this idea?

title: termux-* commands fail when invoked from within Emacs
body:
I installed the termux-api package and app and all termux-* commands work perfectly at the command line. An example is termux-open. If, again within Emacs, I launch the command with 'bash termux-open" I get an error 127. A few things work, like termux-info. The difference seems to be anything that eventually invokes "am" in its script, and the "bash termux-open" example in fact points to the line containing "am" in the termux-open script ("am broadcast ...").

I tried to find the point of failure in "am" and I /think/ but cannot be certain or verify that the problem occurs when "am" reads arguments. 

It's hard to see what's different when running inside Emacs except for environment variables. But it's frustrating as the ability to use things like termux-open, termux-clipboard-*, etc., would be really a big benefit.

title: Terminal output speed issues
body:
This is probably the same as #218 and #368, but I felt that they might not describe the problem adequately.

Terminal output is too slow on many different occasions. When Termux cannot keep up with produced output, it stutters at best and becomes unresponsive for minutes at worst. As far as I can tell, using ANSI escapes (for colors, ncurses ui, etc.) makes things even worse.

Most typical manifestations in my experience:
* Scrolling in `less` and similar utilities. Scrolling down is fine, scronling up redraws whole screen and lags like hell.
* Build logs. Use minimal verbosity and you should be fine. Up verbosity a bit or get a lot of warnings due to a typo in a header, and your terminal is busted. Screen updates once every few seconds, and you'll be catching up with an already finished build for many minutes. (I usually just kill Termux and reconnect to my `tmux` session.)

This has been happening for a long while, half a year at very least. However, after one of the most recent updates (noticed on 0.60), the problem got *much* worse. On my Samsung tablet running Android 5.1.1, 80x25 terminal is mostly bearable, while on 190x40 `vim` takes _almost a minute_ to start and regularly hangs for a few seconds (e.g. on newline entry). Not nearly as bad on my phone running 6.0.1, but still noticeable. 

I haven't yet looked at source code (don't have time right now, neither do I have Android app development experience), but I intend to unless it's fixed in a week or two. I suspect excessive syncing among pty and UI threads and maybe inefficient scrollback handling.

title: Notification lets someone close Termux, or aqcuire / release wakelock when screen is locked
body:
Termux notification has an "exit" button  and an "acquire (release) wakelock" button. These buttons are displayed in the notification even while the screen is locked.

This might allow unwanted closing of Termux (or wakelock release, or battery drain).

Should these buttons be disabled when the screen is locked?

title: Fix for #572 using recursive delete
body: Also see #578 for a merging alternative WIP

title: Fix for #572: merge ~/storage instead of del
body:
We could recursively delete, as in the method above, but that would
require a separate try block for a separate logcat message, or a
different method that returns a flag. I prefer merging in case of custom
folders. Another alternative may be to send an exit code or something for
the termux-setup-storage script to detect and echo an error message.

title: Root shell doesn't recognize non-character keys
label: [Label(name="Feedback needed")]
body:
Please check the [video](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33077154/35867399-edf137cc-0b59-11e8-802b-8201f7ab4d97.gif) I recorded. Non-character keys are actually handled as expected, but immediate visual response only represents the related escape sequence - it's difficult, when not impossible, to take advantage of auto-completion, history and such. This happens in Termux with both `su` and `tsu` scripts and is keyboard-independent; root shells behave correctly in other terminal apps and over adb.
I'm using MAGISKSU binary from Magisk 15.3 on Oreo 8.0; my device is a Moto Z2 Force. Not sure if that was happening even on Nougat.

title: Handling ACTION_EDIT in TermuxOpenReceiver
body:
Firstly, thanks so much for making such an awesome app!  I love termux.

I'm trying to launch an external activity from within termux while giving it the ability to write to a file (or, if possible, a FIFO).

It would appear that TermuxOpenReceiver can almost handle my needs, except that it is currently only designed to handle read-only access.  Having the ability to edit files from other apps would be very useful for me.

I would therefore kindly request that TermuxOpenReceiver handle `ACTION_EDIT`, in which case it would add the flag `Intent.FLAG_GRANT_WRITE_URI_PERMISSION` as well as open the file descriptor using `ParcelFileDescriptor.MODE_READ_WRITE`.  (Perhaps it is also necessary to add an `android:writePermission` attribute to the `<provider>` tag in AndroidManifest.xml?)

Finally, it is currently restricted to files only due to an `isFile()` check.  Could it be changed to `exists()` instead?  I'm hoping that I could get it to work with a named pipe rather than a regular file so that I could pipe data from the activity back to the terminal.

title: Better hotkey support for hardware keyboards
body:
On Chromebooks and external keyboards without physical PgUp, PgDown, Home, etc. keys it'd be great to have hotkey support within Termux.

https://termux.com/touch-keyboard.html documents this sort of hotkey support for phones by using the Volume Up button but this isn't practical for users who aren't on phones. Would be great to have these hotkeys configurable.

title: Feature request: Option to (temporarily) hide the row with special on-screen keys, e.g., when a bluetooth keyboard is attached
body:
Users can long-press on the "keyboard" button in the sidebar to show a row of special on-screen keys. This makes termux much more accessible when users use non-specialized on-screen keyboards.

If users connect to a bluetooth/usb keyboard, the on-screen keyboard is hidden but the extra row is still being displayed and wastes screen space. While users could of course switch the row with special keys off by long-pressing on the "keyboard" button, I think this is unnecessarily cumbersome.

I would like to suggest to implement either one of the following changes:

1. Hide the row, when the on-screen keyboard is hidden.
2. Hide the row, when a hardware keyboard (bluetooth or usb) is being used.

I think this would improve the usability of termux.

title: arm build of bash does not handle keys correctly with TERM=xterm
body:
I am running termux on two different phones, one being aarch64 and the other being arm:
```
bash-4.4$ set | grep BASH_VER
BASH_VERSINFO=([0]="4" [1]="4" [2]="12" [3]="1" [4]="release" [5]="aarch64-unknown-linux-android")
BASH_VERSION='4.4.12(1)-release'
```
and
```
bash-4.4$ set | grep BASH_VER
BASH_VERSINFO=([0]="4" [1]="4" [2]="12" [3]="1" [4]="release" [5]="arm-unknown-linux-androideabi")
BASH_VERSION='4.4.12(1)-release'
```
If I use putty with xterm settings and connect to the phones and press pos1, both receive the same keycodes (sh will print the same output for the key). However for some reason the arm build of bash produces a ~ instead of going to the beginning of the current input line. The end key shows the same behaviour. Also While F1-F12 show the same output in sh on both system, the output produced for some keys in bash is different.
Term variable is correctly identified as "xterm" on both system and stty shows the same settings.
Is there any setting I've missed or is this really a bug in the arm build of bash?

title: Add a custom url handler
body:
I would like to be able to use QR code scans in scripts. Currently I do this by using sharing the scanned barcode with termux and using a custom file editor script. This works, but it is not ideal as the scanned barcode has to be saved in `~/downloads`. I found out that I could launch the barcode scanner by running
```shell
termux-open zxing://scan/?ret=http://ddg.gg={CODE}
```
This will perform a search using the scanned barcode in duckduckgo. Is it possible to replace the return url with a custom version like `termux://myscript/{CODE}`, that would pass the results of the scan to a script called `myscipt`?

title: grep only greps visible characters - screen width dependent
body:
Strange behaviour noticed when writing a bash script which grepped for a command in ps x
The command was long, and if typed at the terminal would go off the screen when vertical, but not when horizontal.
Result, even in the script where no ps screen output was generated, the bash script failed in vertical orientation, but succeeded in horizontal orientation.
This suggests that grep is ignoring all characters in an output which are beyond the screen width.
Steps to reproduce:
Start playing something using mpv
Then type:
ps x | grep mpv
Observe how this succeeds if screen is horizontal, but fails if vertical

title: Support multicast DNS (mdns) via MulticastLock
body:
Hi, I am trying to use Termux to share files between my android and laptop, but I can't get any code that uses multicast DNS to work. I believe it is because Termux needs to request a MulticastLock: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13221736/android-device-not-receiving-multicast-package/13223018#13223018

To test if it's working, do `pkg install node` and then `npm install multicast-dns` and then run `node example.js` with this example: https://github.com/mafintosh/multicast-dns/blob/master/example.js. You should see multicast traffic from your network, including your own query.

title: SSHD running after exiting Termux
body:
Hey, first of all, thanks to the devs for the amazing work they're doing.

I noticed that when starting sshd and then exiting Termux, one can still acess the sshd server. Now it's normal given that it's a daemon and it should be running, but I still wanted to open a ticket for two main reasons:
- If it's not the desired behavior and it is a bug, then probably add it to the pending list.
- If it's not a bug, maybe reconsider the pros and cons of such policy, because particularly for SSHd and no _fail2ban-like_ system, it could pose a threat to the user if the sshd server is always running. 

Anyway, thanks for the amazing work ladies and gentlemen.

title: Ansi sequence for clicks sometime out of range
label: [Label(name="bug report")]
body:
Hi!

I noticed that the ANSI escape sequences that Termux send to applications that corresponds to clicks sometimes are out of range. This happens when clicking between the display and the keyboard. This has the unfortunate consequence that it confuses applications like Emacs.

Background:

When touching the Termux screen, the following escape sequence is emitted:

    ESC [ < 0 ; COL ; LINE M ESC [ < 0 ; COL ; LINE m

Where COL and LINE represent the column and the line if the click, encoded as ascii strings.

When clicking on the first line, the LINE is "1". When clicking on the last line of, say, a display ten lines high, it is "10".

The problem occurs if you tap the screen a little bit below the display, but above the keyboard. Then LINE will be "11", which is out of range. This, unfortunately, triggers Emacs into believing that you clicked on the menu bar.

I haven't checked if the same problem exists for COL, but presumably it does.

If you want to check the escape sequences that Termux emits, you can start Emacs. Click on various locations and then type C-h l (which runs the command `view-lossage`). You will also note that if you tap very low on the screen, the text "Menu Bar (up/down ..." appears in the minibuffer, which it shouldn't.

This doesn't appear to be a problem when the keyboard is hidden.

    -- Anders Lindgren

title: Zsh failing with unsetopt CASE_GLOB (case-insensitive glob matching)
body:
On a clean Termux installation:

```
$ pkg install -y zsh git
...
$ zsh
$ git clone --recursive https://github.com/Eriner/zim.git ~/.zim
...
$ ls ~/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_*_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_eriner_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_gitster_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_lean_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_liquidprompt_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_magicmace_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_minimal_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_pure_setup
/data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_steeef_setup
$ unsetopt CASE_GLOB
$ ls ~/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_*_setup
zsh: no matches found: /data/data/com.termux/files/home/.zim/modules/prompt/functions/prompt_*_setup
$
```

Unseting `CASE_GLOB` means disabling case-sensitive matching in globs. According to the [docs](http://zsh.sourceforge.net/Doc/Release/Options.html#Expansion-and-Globbing):

>  If the option is unset, the presence of any character which is special to filename generation will cause case-insensitive matching. For example, `cvs(/)` can match the directory `CVS` owing to the presence of the globbing flag [...]

In the scenario above, it is expected that the second `ls` call would yield the same results as the first one.

title: Packages upgrade fails with dpkg unpack needs at least one argument
Optionally disable font change on pinch zoom gesture
body:
Among many other usages Termux is excellent for reading manpages or browsing the source code using vim. For this purpose I get rid of the onscreen keyboard and use a finger to scroll the text up. However, sometimes for some unknown reason the movement of the finger is interpreted as "pinch zoom" gesture and the font size is increased or decreased. This is very annoying as one has to bring it back to how it was and it is never exactly that, the difference in font sizes causing eye strain (this is the same reason, btw, why you can't use "auto-crop margins" function in a pdf/djvu document reader if your book has stuff in the margins, because then the font size of text will change from page to page and your eyes will become tired very quickly).

So, if there was a way to disable "pinch zoom" i.e. ignore such gestures in Termux, it would be very useful. Then, such "misinterpreted scroll up attempt" would simply be ignored and one would have to scroll it again, without having to pinch-resize the screen. Thank you.

```
(require 'async)

```

title: How to keep sshd alive
body:
I use sshd in Termux and sshfs in GNU/Linux computer.
So I can access termux files from computer, very useful.

But Android occasionally kills processes even when termux holds wake lock.
When sshd is killed by Android, I cannot access files from computer.
It is VERY VERY FRUSTRATING.

So I create a shell script `ssh-keep-alive' and it is automatically invoked when I USB-connect to computer.

    #!/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/sh
    if ! ssh -p 8022 localhost date +1 | grep 1 > /dev/null; then
        echo $(date) pkill sshd
        pkill sshd
    fi
    if ! pgrep sshd > /dev/null; then
        echo $(date) restart sshd
        sshd
    fi
    sleep 3
    # `adb reverse tcp:9022 tcp:22' is issued in computer
    if ssh rubikitch@localhost -p 9022 date +1 | grep 1 > /dev/null; then
        exec $0
    fi

`ssh-keep-alive' is pseudo URL handler of `termux-url-opener'.

    #!/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/fish
    function invoke-sshd-keep-alive
            echo Invoke ssh-keep-alive
            ssh-keep-alive
    end

    ## stripped

    function _main
            if string match -q http://www.example.com/sshd-keep-alive $argv[1]
                    invoke-sshd-keep-alive
            end
    end

    _main $argv

I execute the following when connect to computer.
Virtually I can execute any command in termux from adb by using `termux-url-opener'.

    $ adb shell am start -a android.intent.action.SEND -t text/plain --es android.intent.extra.TEXT 'http://www.example.com/sshd-keep-alive' -p com.termux

I previously tried to run `ssh-keep-alive' as background process, but Android killed it.
Running `ssh-keep-alive' as foreground process (termux-url-opener), Android does not kill it.

I have rooted my phone.
What is better solution to keep sshd alive?

title: Can't Install NodeJS, Corrupted Filesystem?
body:
Not sure what to do here.

Brand new install of Termux on a rooted Android 5.1 device.  Downloaded Termux from the Google Play store, opened it up, typed `apt install nodejs` and got this result:
```
dpkg: error processing archive: /data/data/com.terumx/files/usr/var/cache/apt/archives/nodejs_8.9.0-1_arm.deb (--unpack):
corrupted filesystem tarfile - corrupted package archive
```

Doing `apt install nodejs-current` provides the same error, only with a different version number in the download.
- Restarting the device didn't help.
- Reinstalling termux didn't help.
- Other packages like Curl and Wget installed just fine.

Google search hasn't turned up anything useful for the error, not sure what to diagnose from here.

Thanks guys.

title: Convert text navigation gestures into arrow key inputs
body:
The Blackberry PRIV and KEYone have gesture capable physical keyboards that allow the moving of the text cursor in standard text inputs, in a mode known as "fine cursor control". It would be great to translate these smoothly into arrow key inputs, to allow fast bash history scrollback, and cursor navigation in programs like vim.

Currently, the "Up" and "Down" gestures already trigger the up and down arrow keys in Termux, but not in a smooth or predictable manner. The left and right gestures currently do nothing.

It's likely that this support would also cover software keyboards that allow cursor movement through built in controls and gestures.

The Blackberry Captivate Keyboard Integration Guide is [here](https://community.blackberry.com/docs/DOC-10328), however it mainly relates to using the keyboard as a trackpad/scroll wheel, which isn't the case when the keyboard is in text input mode (like it always is in termux). Likely the messages it is sending the application in cursor navigation mode are higher level and unrelated.

title: Termux scripts crash when launched from Tasker/Llama (Android 8)

**ISSUE**:
Scripts in the ~/.termux/tasker path launch from Tasker or Llama can be launched and work properly most of the time. Occasionally a job crashes when launched from Tasker or Llama. The script can always be run through a terminal/ssh session without issue.

title: Termux should handle commands spamming the bell better.
body:
```sh
$ mv ~/.termux/termux.properties ~/.termux.properties.bak # reset to vibrate only
<relaunch>
$ while ; do tput bel &; done; # more temporary alternative: cat `which bash`
```
Snap, crackle, pop, until you *force stop*. No other way to stop it. Termux freezes, so you can't Ctrl+C, hit Exit on the notification, or swipe away.
Need I say more?

Ideas:
* Have a minimum delay between bells, probably 25 ms (half vibration time) at the least. This will fix the crackling from the Vibrator trying to activate before it is "ready". If we get any bell signals during that delay, we will wait until that delay is over, then beep/vibrate once:
``` 
Signals: bell bell bell bell bell bell bell bell bell
Output:  bell                bell                bell
Signals: bell     bell     
Output:  bell                bell
Signals: bell                           bell
Output:  bell                           bell
```
* Don't block the thread so the user can Ctrl+C it. This stupidity in the Android OS seems relevant; as it seems that Termux is attempting to run the bell on a separate thread.
> "Like many callbacks from the system, the methods on this class are called from the main thread of your process." — [ServiceConnection documentation](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/ServiceConnection.html)
* If spamming is detected, perhaps give a Snackbar saying something like "A command is repeatedly using the bell." with an option to temporarily silence it.

title: Auto-set TZ environment variable
body:
Hello,

I realized today that the time zone used by emacs to show the time internally was incorrect. i.e. `date` in Termux shows the correct time in correct zone. But time shown within emacs in Termux was BST time zone.

I started this conversation by mistake in the wrong thread [here][1].

Basically emacs relies on the `TZ` environment variable value to show the time correctly -- [[Source][2]].

Copying @Neo-Oli as he helped me confirm this issue. He uses `export TZ=$(getprop persist.sys.timezone)` in his `~/.bash_profile` to get around this issue.

Can this (the `TZ` variable) be set by default?

Thanks.

[1]: https://github.com/termux/termux-packages/issues/1076#issuecomment-328051119
[2]: https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/elisp/Time-Zone-Rules.html

And it definitely works with the "su" from termux not any other probably in path (dircetly called with "/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/su".
But "tsu" searches for "su" only in two hardcoded paths ("/system/xbin/su" and "/su/bin/su") instead using its own su, which searches in "/system/xbin/su", "/system/bin/su", "/su/bin/su", "/sbin/su" and "/magisk/.core/bin/su".

title: SSH on 22 port
body:
Hi,
how can I run `sshd` on port `22` instead of the default `8022`? I have tried and failed to use capabilities for this, see #410

title: Linux capabilities are not effective
body:
Hi,
I've compiled `setcap` and `getcap` for Android and tried to assign `cap_net_bind_service` capability to `sshd`, so I can get it running on port `22` instead of `8022`.

The capability gets set and hence it should work as I am running kernel that supports capabilities. However after restarting the `sshd` process it fails to run without any error message - obviously it won't boot because of the port change (I've tried ports 22, 555). It will start just fine when I return to `Port 8022` in `sshd_config`. I also tried this with SELinux in `Permissive` mode just in case.

__So the `setcap` and `getcap` utils are working just fine, but the kernel is ignoring set capabilities.__ Any ideas?

###### getcap/setcap static compilation
- *you need appropriate hardware/vm*
```
$ wget https://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/libs/security/linux-privs/libcap2/libcap-2.25.tar.gz
$ tar xvfz libcap-2.25.tar.gz
$ cd libcap-2.25
$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install build-essential
$ sed -i.bak "s/DYNAMIC.*/DYNAMIC := no/" Make.Rules
$ make
```

###### installation in termux
```
# setenforce 0

# chmod +x getcap
# chmod +x setcap
$ mv getcap ../usr/bin
$ mv setcap ../usr/bin
```

###### applying the cap_net_bind_service capability
```
# /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/setcap cap_net_bind_service=+ep /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/sshd
$ getcap /data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/sshd
/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/bin/sshd = cap_net_bind_service+ep

$ echo Port 22 >> ../usr/etc/ssh/sshd_config
$ sshd
```

title: Make statusbar transparent
body:
This PR makes the statusbar transparent so it can blend with the current theme. Some notes:

- It affects only API >= 23, so it can turn the statusbar icons dark for light themes.
- It requires an additional property in all themes. You can find the needed changes [in this PR](https://github.com/termux/termux-styling/pull/21). The new property allows two values: dark (by default) and light.

body:
Hi, I've been using Termux for couple of weeks and I can say that is a great app, well done! Although I have a problem, maybe it's a noob problem and I did something wrong, you can help me for sure. I installed Metasploit on Termux, it should work no problem. My problem:

title: Please make termux movable to "external" adopted storage
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="help wanted")]
body:
Hi,

I am trying to use termux on a Samsung Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4" with 16GB internal and 64GB external storage. Tablet is running LineageOS 13.0 (aka Android 6.0.1). Further, I am using nmilosevic's recipe for installing Fedora 25 and 26 under Termux. The problem I am running into relates to Google's inexplicable lack of support for ext4 on external SD cards and the two options I see for using an external SD card with Termux:

1) If I use my external SD card in "adopted storage" mode, Android formats it as ext4 (good), but then I can't move the Termux application to it. Further, termux-setup-storage does not recognize or make links to the external SD card. (In fact, of my "linuxy" apps, only XServer SDL, AndSMB and Hacker's Keyboard appear to be movable, pretty much - for me - defeating the purpose of the external SD card.) I run out of space on the internal SD card fairly quickly, with lots of space wasted on the external SD card.

2) If I use my external SD card in "portable storage" mode, then termux-setup-storage creates links to the external SD card (under /data/data/com.termux/files/home/storage) but since Android formats this as some ridiculous FAT variant (bad), it is useless for installing Fedora onto or for building any of the Linux software that I have written, which exploits/requires UNIX file system permissions.

Consequently, I request that you add the capability of moving the Termux application to external "adopted" storage. By the way, I don't really care that Android thinks my external SD card is "slow" compared to the built-in memory. I can live with slow better than I can live with lack of function.

Your Termux application is - by far - the best Linux under Android solution that I have seen. Unfortunately, all seem to be afflicted by Google's apparent refusal to "support" ext4 - despite using ext4 for Android... I hope the "move" feature is straight-forward to implement. Alternatively, do you have any guidance for how I can accomplish this move?

Thank you!

Dr. Stuart DeGraaf
